Posts.Content: Hi kaz18 lt is a really hard time for you. l know exactly how you feel. l too was diagnosed with Er+  lobular breast cancer in my right breast also at age 48. That was in March 2017. l won't kid you it was the hardest thing l have ever been through and it took away nearly a year of my life. l had a mastectomy with implant reconstruction and I've just had a nipple reconstruction. l also had a full node clearance and 6 EC chemo. It turned out l have 5 areas of globular cancer However l am through the other side. Stronger and happier. You appreciate the small things more.  So you will get through this... surround yourself with family and good friends . Let them help you emotionally and with practical stuff  l lost my hair during chemo and now l have a short pixie cut, but do you know what it's thicker in texture and l like it better
Posts.Title: Hormone positive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: My surgeon seems to like to see his patients a lot. I had the op on Thursday and have seen him Fri, Sat, today and due on Friday. He is so lovely and makes me feel so reassured. I didn't actually ask for the immediate reconstruction on the good breast,  when I saw surgeon pre op he asked me what size I would like the implant ( I didn't expect to get a choice!  - I asked for a D cup --- was a droopy F cup) I said oh my I will look a right lopsided mess and straight away he said no we will do the other side at the same time. At the moment they are swollen but I'm pleased with the size and shape. And best of all when I take my bra off they stay in the same place lol
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi day dream I was wondering how you got on today? k x
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: I feel ok with my implant at the moment. It feels more solid than the other side. I have no nipple either and a t shaped scar. All my drains are out and my dressings off... just got tape on now. Back in a week for a check. I've gone to a similar cup size as you. D/DD. I was an F/FF cup. My reduced uplifted breat has less swelling and is less sore than the implant/mx side. I'm glad I chose to have both done.  I've now got a large genetics questionnaire to complete..... l have a big family history. But my mum a survivor of 33 years. And she took tamoxifen for 14 of them. ( lt was new back then). Cant wait to get more mobile and not be so tired and swollen... current ly looks like or small amd one smaller beach ball.
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Daydream I too have a breast mx with immediate implant 5 days ago. I still have one drain in. Were you emptying and measuring your drain output daily. I was told to do that and that each drain had to get under 50ml before it could come out. I understand that if you have a haematoma the area will be painful, red, swollen and hot. I can understand why you will worry, see the doc or the breast care nurse as soon as you can and they will either put your mind at rest or sort you out. I felt better today after my surgeon redid my dressings and reassured me all was well. I have had a reduction and uplift on the good side too. Tightness is normal, stinging is normal. I know all this as I am a surgery veteran  I have numerous issues and have had numerous big operations. Plenty of rest and look forward to fun things you can do when you are better k x
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Its great that you have seen your surgeon and he was able to relieve a bit of pressure. I hope each day gets better for you with the fluid. I hope to have my last drain out tomorrow. Just cant stop having naps so tired zzzzzzz
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi I too have having a mx this week on the right breast, Im having immediate implant, and the left side reduced and lifted at the same time. I have been told I will be off work for 6 weeks and wont be able to do anything heavy. There is no definite guidance about driving - Im hoping to be able to drive after 4 weeks - I was basically told when Im comfortable and can do an emergency stop. Good luck with your op x
Posts.Title: Implants after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi there My breast cancer was found by pain alone. I had shooting pains in my right breast ... Five years ago I also had a small lump (turned out to be benign , but I also had shooting pains with this), hence why I had my new shooting pains checked out. Nothing showed up on a mammogram but a dodgy area was located with an ultrasound and a biopsy taken, this turned out to be cancerous. MRI located one more area of cancer. One mastectomy later and my right breast was found to contain 5 areas of lobular cancer. I didn't have any other symptoms apart from the shooting pains, no nipple or skin problems and no lump. Having said that most breast pain turns out to be nothing to worry about! I grateful for those shooting pains though... cos at least I found it. It may be worth having an MRI if you haven't already had one.  Wishing you well and hoping that you turn out with no reason for worry K x
Posts.Title: Breast discomfort....

Posts.Content: Hi Bamjoman I only got the pain 3 times and it was a sharp shooting type of pain that started under my armpit and went across to my nipple. It happened 3 times all at night when I had no bra on.  I wouldnt have thought much of it because lm peri menipausal. So woyld have put it down to my age apart from the fact that I had the same pain a few years ago when I found a benign lump.   I didn't honestly think it would am out to anything.  Certainly not 5 seperate areas of lobular cancer. No lumps no change to breast. Very lucky l found it really.  Starting chemo soon.   Yuk
Posts.Title: Breast discomfort....

Posts.Content: Hi ninja warrior  If it makes you feel any better. I have had one EC chemo so far without steroids.  I have had lots of steroids in the past due to crohns and l dont react well to them. I have still had extreme low mood for 5 days and less of appetite I have previously had long term steroid use and my side effects were bloated (moon) face. Sweats. Not sleeping. Hair growth in places t shouldn't be. Uncontrollable hunger and a v short temper and fuse. So it is possibleto have chemo without steroids.  I have filstagram injections instead....
Posts.Title: Delayed docetaxel and now realise how bad the side effects from steroids...

Posts.Content: I have an implant and have just had nipple reconstruction. l know that l can have a surgical tattoo. However, l think l would like something more permanent. l am considering getting a permanent tattoo done by a tattoo artist trained in doing nipple tattoos. Has anyone had this done with an implant?
Posts.Title: Permanent nipple tattoo with implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: Wow Helen they look great. l was just concerned there might be a risk of the implant been punctured by the tattoo as I assume the ink goes deeper than a medical tattoo. l found a lady in Huddersfield and one in Keighley. both trained. And I've seen photos of their work. Will speak to my consultant about it l think.
Posts.Title: Permanent nipple tattoo with implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: Thanks Dreamthief x
Posts.Title: Permanent nipple tattoo with implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Sacha. I can imagine how you feel. I've just had a mx for invasive lobular. I get my results tomorrow and lm more scared of been told l need chemotherapy than l was of the mastectomy.  I've have heard that her2+ ..... chemo will always be recommended.  I'm praying l don't need it. Not least for all my chemo treatment fears but also for rhe length of time off work required and my loss of pay
Posts.Title: Invasive lobular and chemo

Posts.Content: Oh I'm sorry ... My eyesight hasn't been the same since my surgery.... seems my eyes are tired and I misread. Ive been told that I will need tamoxifen but not necessarily chemo. I will see what the outcome of my meeting with the surgeon tomorrow. I suppose at the end of the day we have to do what we have to do to get well
Posts.Title: Invasive lobular and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Andy I hope you doing well on your recovery journey I cant answer your question but will be interested to see the answer. I too am having a mastectomy and instant implant in a couple of weeks. However at the same time I am having a reduction and lift on the 'good' side. I would like to know about bras and holidays too. Are you having any follow up treatments K
Posts.Title: Post mastectomy/reconstruction...Questions

Posts.Content: I have strattice implant dome in May on the NHS is East Yorskhire
Posts.Title: Strattice reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi all I'm new to the forum. I am diagnosed with invasive lobular cancer in two separate areas of one breast. Later this month I am having a mastectomy with implant reconstruction and am having my 'good' breast reduced and lifted. I have been told to get a sports bra for use after surgery. But I'm a larger lady and I'm currently a 40 F. My new cup size will be D-DD. So I'm looking for a 42 DD sports bra. Have looked online (UK) Debenhams, M & S, Evans, Simply Be. The choice is not much and what there is are quite pricey. Can anyone recommend a place to buy a bra, or a make and where to get online. Anyone my sort of size had these issues. On a lighter note I'm looking forward to perky boobs
Posts.Title: Post surgery sports bras

Posts.Content: Thanks for your response Sue. I always try to find humour in my situation. I found it helps those around me cope.
Posts.Title: Post surgery sports bras

Posts.Content: Hi Kitty Cat Hope you are doing ok after your surgery. I did wonder about swelling and if the bras would even fit. I find sports bras really tight anyway. Did the hospital send you home in a compression bra?   And also are you managing to get over the head vests/t shirts on? I think I might consider crop tops and I can see myself having the same problem
Posts.Title: Post surgery sports bras

Posts.Content: Thanks Granny Mush 37,,, £6 sounds like a great price. Have a large Asda George near me so will try one on, although how that will work when I will be a different size... I'm not sure. However just realised I will have to buy all new bras as none of my current ones will fit ........ oh dear.
Posts.Title: Post surgery sports bras

Posts.Content: Hi Val Wow that is some journey just to have a jab. I'm lucky that my cancer centre is 5 miles away. Maybe l will have to ask my oncologist for something to take just before the chemo session. I'm finding it hard to deal with cos I'm normally such a confident person. The surgery... mastectomy and reconstruction, then full lymph mode removal didn't phase me at all. l wasn't nervous. l keep getting angry with myself for been so weak. l will be so glad when it's all over. Exhausted too. Working 3 to 4 hours per day with only the chemo day off. And three step kids 15 and under staying this week
Posts.Title: Chemo induced anxiety & depression

Posts.Content: Hi all. I've had  3 EC chemos now. Ive been really lucky with the physical side effects but the emotional ones.... wow! I've developed an anxiety that appears to be related to anything to do with the chemo. Even if my chemo arm feels bruised and I remember that's where the chemo went in I get all panicky and feel woozy. l can't talk about the chemo .... the thought of my next EC infusion fills me with panic. I've spoken to the BC nurse .. have been referred for counselling. My anti depressants have been changed a week ago to include something to help with anxiety. I've not seen anyone on this site mention anxiety... it's it just me.  I'm very jittery, emotional and nervy. None of which l have ever been before.  Don't really know what else to do to combat this. At the moment I'm not sure l can continue with the chemo kerry
Posts.Title: Chemo induced anxiety & depression
